title: How Trump is winning the fight on 'baseless' ads
text:
Google spokespeople declined Thursday to comment on the letter, but the company said earlier this week that the ad does not violate its policies. Twitter has likewise deemed the ad in compliance, a spokesperson said.

But Democrats say the dominant online platforms are once again bending or ignoring their own policies against targeted harassment, hate speech and misinformation when it comes to Trump — a decision that will have major implications for the political ads that tens of millions of voters see between now and Election Day. The 2020 presidential candidates have spent more than $50 million on Facebook ads alone through Saturday, according to figures compiled by POLITICO, with Trump’s $14.4 million total leading the field by far.

The online companies’ decisions are in keeping with recent statements from top Silicon Valley executives who said they will give a wide berth to speech by political leaders, despite policies that otherwise restrict or prohibit false or demeaning content. That stance also avoids putting them further in the crosshairs of Trump and other Republicans who have accused the tech giants of censoring conservatives.

To Democrats, though, the trend inspires troubling reminders of 2016, when social media companies failed to halt election disinformation as Russian-linked trolls ginned up fake news about Hillary Clinton.

"TV stations and social media companies, like Facebook, should refuse to air these baseless ads, which are purposefully meant to deceive voters,” Sabrina Singh, a spokesperson for Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.), told POLITICO. “We should have all learned the lessons from 2016 and social media companies should have to bear more responsibility to prevent lies from being spread against anyone."

A spokesperson for another Democratic hopeful, former Texas Rep. Beto O’Rourke, called the episode “just another example of Facebook failing to take its responsibility to its users — and our country — seriously.”

“Misinformation is misinformation, whether it’s from Russian trolls or Presidents, and Facebook needs to do better," said the spokesperson, Aleigha Cavalier.

The Trump campaign says the Biden ad is true, so keeping it up is totally appropriate.

“The truth hurts and our ads are 100 percent accurate,” campaign communications director Tim Murtaugh told POLITICO.

The ad alleges that as vice president, Biden threatened to withhold $1 billion in aid to Ukraine unless it fired a prosecutor investigating Burisma, a Ukrainian energy company where his son was a director. In fact, a broad, bipartisan consensus existed at the time in the U.S. and abroad that the prosecutor was failing to probe corruption in the country, including at Burisma — and no evidence has emerged to support the accusation that Biden was acting to protect his son.

Social media isn’t the only place where people can see the ad, which also has also run on Fox and MSNBC. But the online platforms have huge reach — Facebook has more than 2 billion members worldwide — and an unmatched ability to target messages to specific groups of voters, making them an important messaging battleground for 2020.

This is just the latest dust-up between Trump’s Democratic critics and the social media companies over how they handle his often incendiary posts and tweets. Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) has called on Twitter to suspend Trump’s personal account over tweets in which he blasted House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) and suggested that the House’s impeachment effort would lead to “civil war.” The company has yet to formally respond to the request, according to a Harris campaign spokesperson, but Trump’s account has remained active, even as a growing number of Democratic officials have called for the company to step in.

In July, Twitter similarly refused to take down tweets in which Trump called House Oversight Chairman Elijah Cummings’ (D-Md.) majority-black Baltimore-area district a “ disgusting, rat and rodent infested mess” and urged four Democratic congresswomen of color to “go back” to the “crime infested places from which they came." One of those congresswomen, Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.), told POLITICO in September that Twitter should suspend Trump's account.

Free speech advocates say the Democrats’ calls for Silicon Valley to play political gatekeeper risk trampling on constitutionally protected political discourse.

“It's not Facebook's job to moderate our political debates,” said Jesse Blumenthal, vice president of technology and innovation at the Stand Together coalition, which is backed by the libertarian Koch family. “It's up to each American to be an informed citizen — and social media meaningfully enables more speech, which is a good thing.”

The companies have offered similar explanations of their policies, even as they have faced rising pressure to squelch hate, bullying and fake news.

In rejecting Biden’s request to take down the Trump ad, Facebook wrote that its decision was based on a “fundamental belief in free expression, respect for the democratic process, and the belief that, in mature democracies with a free press, political speech is already arguably the most scrutinized speech there is.”

Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications, former British Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, said at a conference last month in Washington that “it is not our role to intervene when politicians speak. … We do not submit speech by politicians to our independent fact-checkers, and we generally allow it on the platform even when it would otherwise breach our normal content rules.”

YouTube has told POLITICO that it doesn’t offer special treatment to politicians, who must abide by its community guidelines. But CEO Susan Wojcicki said at the same September conference that “when you have a political officer that is making information that is really important for their constituents to see, or for other global leaders to see, that is content that we would leave up because we think it's important for other people to see."

Presidential candidates like Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) say tech companies’ decision to keep up misleading election-related ads poses “a serious concern for our democratic process.” She suggested in a series of tweets that Facebook’s actions in particular indicate that the company is “taking deliberate steps to help one candidate intentionally mislead the American people,” to the disadvantage of other campaigns like hers.

That argument resonated with one prominent tech mogul, Facebook co-founder-turned-critic Chris Hughes, who said this week that “by deciding to allow outright lies in political ads to travel on Facebook,” CEO Mark Zuckerberg “is embracing the philosophy behind Trumpism and thereby tipping the scales.”

Others see a more direct cause linking Facebook, Twitter and YouTube’s decision to stand down on Trump’s ads.

Tim Karr, senior director of strategy and communications for the group Free Press, said cracking down on misleading advertising would simply be bad for business, given the millions of dollars that Trump's campaign has poured into political ads across the big social media platforms. “In truth, this decision may be more about profits than principle,” he said.

Heavily policing the candidates’ ads would also risk stirring up even more GOP allegations that Silicon Valley stifles conservative speech and makes it hard to find or follow right-leaning voices online. The president has frequently amplified that accusation, even holding a daylong “summit” at the White House on the topic in July.

Indeed, Twitter is still facing Republican attacks over its October 2017 decision to block then-Rep. Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.) from advertising a Senate campaign launch video that included what it called “inflammatory” language about Planned Parenthood and “the sale of baby body parts.” Twitter caved in a day later.

Hence the reluctance to drop the hammer on Trump now, some observers of the industry’s practices suggested.

“It's reasonable to conclude that Twitter is simply avoiding conflict with their most famous user and his political party,” said Alex Howard, director of the Digital Democracy Project at Demand Progress. “Whether that's because of past bad faith arguments designed to chill the company's arbitration of rules on its own platform or not is not clear, but it's likely.”
